summary: It's not that I don't love Tony Stark,
body:
It’s not that I don’t love Tony Stark,

I do.

I love him.

That’s all.

That’s all.

I do.

That’s all.

I do.

I love him.

That’s all.

title: Ironbaby part 2
body:
Pepper: How about Peter for a boy? I like the name Peter.

Tony. No, we can’t call the baby Peter.

Pepper: Why not?

Tony: Because I already have a…..

Pepper: You already have a what?

Tony: I mean, it might get confusing, because, you know, Peter…..

Pepper: Peter Parker is not your son, Tony.

Peter: *Swooping in* Hi Dad, did you call?

title: 3 am thoughts ...
body:
Depression isn’t just about having thoughts about ‘ending it all’ It’s that feeling that you just have no energy to take a shower, sometimes for days; or can’t manage much more then watching tv all day and napping intermittently.

   It’s 3:45am but these feelings exist at any time of day but this is always when we’re the most honest it seems isn’t it. Least this is when i most want to talk to someone who understands me but there is none.

   It’s not just about popping pills or such it’s also about feeling like you live in a basement with no sunlight and all you want to do is have that beautiful view you once had back again. Or even just a view … to be able to open a window with fresh air.  

   Being so so tired of having to be your own light and strength.

   I haven’t gone about my normal routine in weeks, months even and no one has checked on me. No one. Because i am the one who checks on others. I’m always ‘fine’ and appear to have it together. Heck i’ve ‘been there’ for several people without them knowing i’m struggling too.

   I also have a horrible self sabotage issue where i become my own worst enemy especially when i also struggle with anxiety and ocd (which is not just about people washing their hands a million times either).  There are ways to harm yourself besides the physical ways.

   This shit tries to steal you from yourself but you’re the only one who can save yourself (or that’s what you think/feel) but you haven’t enough energy or strength alone and it’s a vicious cycle that’s hard to break out of.

   So you end up beating yourself up for not being the best version of yourself you can be because you know you know better or can do better but you have failed yourself even if you are trying.  And you also feel worse wishing for that knight and shining armor to save the day for you because you know you can save yourself , you have to but so far you’ve failed

   It’s wishing more then anything to find and be with the person you love and for them to love you back but knowing you might always be alone because you are just so messed up and having that sadness consume any productive action or thoughts.  When i say sadness i don’t mean 24/7 crying but that blanket of fog that taints everything; a constant mist you are trying to find your way out of.

   Depression isn’t just about loneliness either but it’s kind of also feeling like you’re trapped in your own reality but on the sidelines behind an invisible barrier watching everyone march past you. Forgetting you …

   just 3 am thoughts … and feelings …

blog.name: davidmann95
blog.title: Not Even 50% Of My TRUE Power
blog.description: Comics guy, writer guy, Superman guy

summary: Bit more in your wheelhouse: I've been making my way through the 70th Anniversary Special one-shots featuring their Golden Age...
question: Bit more in your wheelhouse: I've been making my way through the 70th Anniversary Special one-shots featuring their Golden Age characters that Marvel put out in 2009, and I was wondering if you'd read any of 'em & if so had any thoughts. Ditto the 2011 miniseries Mystery Men: The Golden Age (the one with new/original, more pulp-y heroes in the pre-Golden Age Marvel Universe), which one of the aforementioned is collected with cuz they share a writer.
answer:
Never read ‘em. This did remind me, however, of a very different set of anniversary titles Marvel put out for their 75th I’ve been thinking about recently: the Marvel 100th Anniversary books, imagining what their core titles might look like in 2061 (100 years after the debut of the Fantastic Four, rather than the company itself). While I’d only call two out of the five one-shots necessarily ‘good’, it remains one of my favorite weird mini-events of this sort, since the central conceit isn’t that it’s decades in the future with characters telling their last stories, but what their ‘normal’ published adventures in those times look like. Without spoiling the contents for those who might want to check these out: 

* Jen Van Meter and Joanna Estep’s Fantastic Four - which admittedly does make the time jump unlike the others, though I sort of appreciate that that means none of these are operating on the same page, going wholly with their own interpretation of the conceit - embraces its status as a family legacy book and shows a fundamentally altered team and dynamic, while still adhering to its core and bringing back all the stuff we’ve theoretically missed for awhile in 2061 without compromising what’s worked since. A sweet, satisfying offering.

* Spider-Man goes all-in on being a random issue off tomorrow’s spinner rack, identifying itself in the recap page as the finale of an eight-part arc (writer Sean Ryan even mentioned having planned out the previous seven issues in an interview, including a major part for Silver Sable that’s not mentioned at all in what we got) and acting as an all-action showdown since the emotional context theoretically would have been established by the lead-in. It’s not great given that, well, we didn’t get any of the build-up, and the dialogue can be pretty on the nose. But In-Hyuk Lee’s art is gorgeously haunting, and Ryan knows how to play into it and more importantly when to shut up, the two working to give this a mood unlike any other Spider-Man story I’ve ever read. If nothing else, as a statement on the future it’s inspiring to think the main Spider-Man title would be permitted the sort of time between issues Lee’s art would surely require, a victory of quality over quantity. Plus, as far as I know, the cover of this was the only comic of the last who-knows-how-long to use my favorite version of the Spider-Man title logo.

* Robin Furth and Jason Masters’ X-Men is the one of these that really and truly pissed me off, an awkwardly written and weakly penciled ode to plowing over everything interesting that’s been done with the X-Men since the turn of the century, and all the potential yet to come, in favor of returning everything to an eternal Claremontian wonderland, with a bit of “we need to take things slow to beat racism, rushing it’s just gonna get people madder” spice to really hammer home how hard this drops the ball. Yet it feels an appropriate part of this set, an unintentional yet necessary cautionary tale that particularly contrasts well with Fantastic Four’s embrace of past and present alike in search of a brighter future.

* James Stokoe’s Avengers is the obvious standout, from the bananas recap page to the deluge of concepts and that good good gooooooood Stokoe art. At the same time, while it’s primarily a straightforward adventure (indeed, while Spider-Man makes the biggest show of us joining in medias res with no context due to having this essentially plucked out of time, this is the issue that truly feels the most like a random future Marvel comic rather than a specially chosen anniversary issue), there’s an underlying, relatively subtle meditation on the fundamentally inflexible natures of these characters even as their status quos and the world around them shift. One concluding with a change in their usual tactics that suggests that in spite of that, they can still adapt to the times and become better with time, as heroes in the story and as role models outside of it. This is the comic that not only most feels like it was delivered to us from the future, but the one I most want to believe really does give us a glimpse at what Marvel will one day become.

* Andy Lanning, Ron Marz, and Gustavo Duarte’s Guardians of the Galaxy is a comic I factually know I read at some point, since I got it on Comixology years after the fact, but as I recall there’s just nothing there. And perhaps in that regard it’s the truest, most inevitable image of tomorrow of them all: whatever comics may become, the fact of the matter is that as with every other creative medium, there will always, even in 2061, be some stuff that’s just whatever.

This did remind me, however, of a very different set of anniversary titles Marvel put out for their 75th I’ve been thinking about recently: the Marvel 100th Anniversary books, imagining what their core titles might look like in 2061 (100 years after the debut of the Fantastic Four, rather than the company itself). While I’d only call two out of the five one-shots necessarily ‘good’, it remains one of my favorite weird mini-events of this sort, since the central conceit isn’t that it’s decades in the future with characters telling their last stories, but what their ‘normal’ published adventures in those times look like. Without spoiling the contents for those who might want to check these out: 

* Jen Van Meter and Joanna Estep’s Fantastic Four - which admittedly does make the time jump unlike the others, though I sort of appreciate that that means none of these are operating on the same page, going wholly with their own interpretation of the conceit - embraces its status as a family legacy book and shows a fundamentally altered team and dynamic, while still adhering to its core and bringing back all the stuff we’ve theoretically missed for awhile in 2061 without compromising what’s worked since. A sweet, satisfying offering.

* Spider-Man goes all-in on being a random issue off tomorrow’s spinner rack, identifying itself in the recap page as the finale of an eight-part arc (writer Sean Ryan even mentioned having planned out the previous seven issues in an interview, including a major part for Silver Sable that’s not mentioned at all in what we got) and acting as an all-action showdown since the emotional context theoretically would have been established by the lead-in. It’s not great given that, well, we didn’t get any of the build-up, and the dialogue can be pretty on the nose. But In-Hyuk Lee’s art is gorgeously haunting, and Ryan knows how to play into it and more importantly when to shut up, the two working to give this a mood unlike any other Spider-Man story I’ve ever read. If nothing else, as a statement on the future it’s inspiring to think the main Spider-Man title would be permitted the sort of time between issues Lee’s art would surely require, a victory of quality over quantity. Plus, as far as I know, the cover of this was the only comic of the last who-knows-how-long to use my favorite version of the Spider-Man title logo.

* Robin Furth and Jason Masters’ X-Men is the one of these that really and truly pissed me off, an awkwardly written and weakly penciled ode to plowing over everything interesting that’s been done with the X-Men since the turn of the century, and all the potential yet to come, in favor of returning everything to an eternal Claremontian wonderland, with a bit of “we need to take things slow to beat racism, rushing it’s just gonna get people madder” spice to really hammer home how hard this drops the ball. Yet it feels an appropriate part of this set, an unintentional yet necessary cautionary tale that particularly contrasts well with Fantastic Four’s embrace of past and present alike in search of a brighter future.

* James Stokoe’s Avengers is the obvious standout, from the bananas recap page to the deluge of concepts and that good good gooooooood Stokoe art. At the same time, while it’s primarily a straightforward adventure (indeed, while Spider-Man makes the biggest show of us joining in medias res with no context due to having this essentially plucked out of time, this is the issue that truly feels the most like a random future Marvel comic rather than a specially chosen anniversary issue), there’s an underlying, relatively subtle meditation on the fundamentally inflexible natures of these characters even as their status quos and the world around them shift. One concluding with a change in their usual tactics that suggests that in spite of that, they can still adapt to the times and become better with time, as heroes in the story and as role models outside of it. This is the comic that not only most feels like it was delivered to us from the future, but the one I most want to believe really does give us a glimpse at what Marvel will one day become.

* Andy Lanning, Ron Marz, and Gustavo Duarte’s Guardians of the Galaxy is a comic I factually know I read at some point, since I got it on Comixology years after the fact, but as I recall there’s just nothing there. And perhaps in that regard it’s the truest, most inevitable image of tomorrow of them all: whatever comics may become, the fact of the matter is that as with every other creative medium, there will always, even in 2061, be some stuff that’s just whatever.

title: Goddess of Deception
body:
Runa Thorsdotter, Daughter of Thor, Agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. hides who she really is, until she meets Loki, who encourages her to be her true self.

What is Love?

November 17th, 2013The Bifrost sends us to the patio of Jane’s apartment. Jane runs up to Thor and kisses him. I walk past them while they make out on the patio. I walk inside.“Anyone have a phone…

Read more…
